fields.descriptive_line: Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara, copper alloy, Andhra Pradesh, Deccan, late 7th century.
fields.physical_description: The figure of which the lower part is missing from below the breast, may possibly represent the Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara.  It was probably made in the eastern Deccan where many Buddhist bronzes have been found, especially in the Krishna Delta, and falls between the traditions of the north-west Deccan and developments in southern India, Sri Lanka and South-east Asia.  The left hand is in a position of kataka mudra, and as though holding a lotus.  The upper garment is worn in sacred-thread style (vastra-vajnopavita), the ends hanging loose behind and extending to the elbow.  The hair is dressed high in ascetic fashion (jata makuta), and two long braided strands hang down to the shoulders, terminating in loose curls.  The jata is decked in front with a flower, and on the lower forehead there is a faint  trace of a lightly engraved circle indicating a mahapurusha lakshana (conventional sign of distinction).  Ear lobes are extended and each decorated with a small bead or pearl.  A single bangle is worn on the left wrist.
fields.dimensions: Height: 15 cm Maximum (head to elbow), Height: 13.5 cm Head to waist, Width: 11 cm Maximum
fields.title: Sculpture

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.bibliography: See V.Smith History of Fine Art, pl.XLVI, and fig 158. D.Barrett, The later school of Amaravati and its influences, Art and letters, Vol. XXVIII, 1954. P.Sewell, some Buddhist bronzes, J.R.A.S, 1895, figs.2 & 3. J. Irwin, " SouthIndian Figure sculpture, 7th to 10th Century, A.D. J,R,A.S. Oct. 1948, pp 105-7, pl.1. The art of Greater India, Los Angeles County Museum, 1950, p.35 and pl. 59. C. Sivaramamurti, <u>South Indian Bronzes</u>, Lalit Kala Akademi, New Delhi, 1963, pp. 45, 69, plate 2b. W.Zwalf, Buddhism-Art and Faith, British Museum 1985. Pratapaditya, Pal, Two Sinhalese Bronze Bodhisattva Images in the Norton Simon Museum, Vnanamala, Festschrift A.J.Gail, Gerd J.R.Mevissen et Klaus Bruhn redigerunt, Weidler, Berlin 2006. Guy, John. 'Buddhist Bronzes of Southern India : Rediscovering a Lost History' in Arts of Asia, volume 30 number 6, Nov-Dec 2000, pp.103-110. Pal, Pratapaditya, <u>The Elegant Image: Bronzes from the Indian Subcontinent in the Siddharth K. Bhansali Collection</u>, Marg and New Orleans Museum of Art, 2011, p. 110.
fields.history_note: Purchased from Robert Sewell Esq., in 1914 for £3.
fields.production_note: Deccan, from the Krsna Delta,  Pallava dynasty, Andhra Pradesh.
fields.historical_context_note: This image is a rare survivor of early southern Indian bronze casting.   The cult-specific features are not present here, so this image could conceivably be either of the principal Buddhist saviours (bodhisattvas), Maitreya or Avalokitesvara). A very similar style Bodhisattva metal image was recovered in peninsular Thailand, with an Amitabha image in the headdress, confirming that sculpture's identity as Avalokitesvara.
